byline.contributor: Amy Chozick contributed reporting from Everett, Wash., and Matt Flegenheimer and Thomas Kaplan from New York.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and MAGGIE HABERMAN

abstract: Terrorist threat highlighted by Brussels attacks generates uncertainty for American presidential contenders, whose security strategies and responses are shaped and viewed through lens of events abroad and different primary electorates the candidates face; bombing has rekindled debate over whether to use diplomacy, isolation or military strength to battle Islamic State and other extremist groups.

headline.print_headline: In Campaign, Walking a Tightrope Over the Fight Against ISIS
headline.main: Presidential Candidates Walking a Tightrope Over the Fight on Terrorism

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: In the current atmosphere, a strike like the one on Tuesday in Brussels rekindles every debate about whether the United States should use diplomacy, isolation or military might.
lead_paragraph: In the current atmosphere, a strike like the one on Tuesday in Brussels rekindles every debate about whether the United States should use diplomacy, isolation or military might.
